{"step_by_step_thinking": "The patient's presentation is consistent with metatarsus adductus, a common foot deformity in newborns where the front half of the foot, or forefoot, turns inward. This condition is often associated with intrauterine molding factors such as oligohydramnios and breech presentation, both of which are present in this case. The key to diagnosis is the ability to passively correct the deformity, as seen when tickling the lateral border of the foot leads to correction of the deformity. This indicates that the condition is flexible and will likely resolve spontaneously over time. Therefore, the most appropriate next step in management is reassurance.", "answer_choice": "C. Reassurance"}
